newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria to set price limits for basic foods.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria to set price limits for basic foods.

text.p: Bulgaria's cabinet on Thursday decided to impose maximum price limits for basic foods in a bid to counter profiteering amid rising inflation sparked by a falling lev and economic instablity, an official said.

"The government is introducing maximum acceptable prices for flour, bread, cooking oil, milk, butter and cheese," the National Prices Commitee chairman Dimitar Grivekov told reporters after the cabinet's regular weekly session.
Under the new pricing scheme the allowed profit for food producers will be raised by six points to 18 percent of costs and for traders it will stay unchanged at 14 percent, Grivekov added.
The highest permitted price levels are expected to be determined after discussions with the respective producers' unions, Grivekov added.
Consumer price inflation has soared to a cumulative 113 percent for the first eight months after reaching a record high of 23.3 percent in July.
Inflation in Bulgaria is closely linked to the lev/ dollar exchange rate and inflation rate rises in proportion to the dollar rise against the local currency.
The lev has lost 230 percent of its value against the dollar since the beginning of the year.

The government's decision to reimpose price controls is the first since February 1990, when the first post-communist interim government of Dimitar Popov lifted most price controls to offset grave shortages.
"Setting fixed prices (for foods) is not possible because the state has no money to subsidise producers," Grevekov said. @
